title: inverse of an integer matrix
description: Question I've been working on this for a long time and I'm getting nowhere. Could you help me or at least tell me where to look for help. Suppose D is an m-by-m diagonal matrix with integer elements all . Suppose X is an m-by-n integer matrix . Consider the partitioned matrix M = [D X]. Obviously M has full row rank so it has a right inverse of rational numbers. The question is, under what conditions does it have an integer right inverse? My guess, which I can't prove, is that the integers in each row need to be relatively prime.

title: Sticky Cantor sets
description: Conjecture Let be a Cantor set embedded in .  Is there a self-homeomorphism of for every greater than so that moves every point by less than and does not intersect ?  Such an embedded Cantor set for which no such exists (for some ) is called sticky.  For what dimensions do sticky Cantor sets exist?

title: Strong 5-cycle double cover conjecture

title: Square achievement game on an n x n grid
description: Problem Two players alternately write O's (first player) and X's (second player) in the unoccupied cells of an grid.     The first player (if any) to occupy four cells at the vertices of a square with horizontal and vertical sides is the winner.  What is        the outcome of the game given optimal play?               Note: Roland Bacher and Shalom Eliahou proved that every 15 x 15 binary matrix contains four equal entries (all 0's or all 1's) at the vertices of a square with horizontal and vertical sides.  So the game must result in a winner (the first player) when n=15.

categories: Graph Theory, Topological G.T., Planar graphs

title: Barnette's Conjecture

title: Covering a square with unit squares
description: Conjecture For any integer , it is impossible to cover a square of side greater than with unit squares.

title: Sequence defined on multisets
description: Conjecture Define a array of positive integers where the first row consists  of some distinct positive integers arranged in increasing order, and the second row consists of any positive  integers in any order.  Create a new array where the first row consists of all the integers that occur in the first array, arranged in increasing order, and the second row consists of their multiplicities.   Repeat the process.   For example, starting with the  array , the sequence is: $-> -> -> -> -> -> -> -> -> -> ->$ , and we now have a fixed point (loop of one array). The process always results in a loop of 1, 2, or 3 arrays.

title: Vertex Coloring of graph fractional powers
description: Conjecture Let be a graph and be a positive integer. The power of , denoted by , is defined on the vertex set , by connecting any two distinct vertices and with distance at most . In other words, . Also subdivision of , denoted by , is constructed by replacing each edge of with a path of length . Note that for , we have . Now we can define the fractional power of a graph as follows: Let be a graph and . The graph is defined by the power of the subdivision of . In other words . Conjecture. Let be a connected graph with and be a positive integer greater than 1. Then for any positive integer , we have . In [1], it was shown that this conjecture is true in some special cases.
kwds: chromatic number, fractional power of graph, clique number

title: Snevily's conjecture
description: Conjecture Let be an abelian group of odd order and let satisfy .  Then the elements of and may be ordered and so that the sums are pairwise distinct.

title: 3-flow conjecture
description: Conjecture Every 4- edge-connected graph has a nowhere-zero 3-flow.

title: Sets with distinct subset sums

title: Seymour's Second Neighbourhood Conjecture
description: Conjecture Any oriented graph has a vertex whose outdegree is at most its second outdegree.

title: Which lattices occur as intervals in subgroup lattices of finite groups?
description: Conjecture There exists a finite lattice that is not an interval in the subgroup lattice of a finite group.

title: Quartic rationally derived polynomials
description: Conjecture There does not exist a quartic rationally derived polynomial with four distinct roots.

title: Nonseparating planar continuum
description: Conjecture Does any path-connected, compact set in the plane which does not separate the plane have the fixed point property? A set has the fixed point property if every continuous map from it into  itself has a fixed point.

title: Hilbert-Smith conjecture
description: Conjecture Let be a locally compact topological group.  If has a continuous faithful group action on an -manifold, then is a Lie group .

title: Real roots of the flow polynomial
description: Conjecture All real roots of nonzero flow polynomials are at most 4.

title: Finite Lattice Representation Problem

title: The 4x5 chessboard complex is the complement of a link, which link?
description: Problem Ian Agol and Matthias Goerner observed that the 4x5 chessboard complex is the complement of many distinct links in the 3-sphere. Their observation is non-constructive, as it uses the resolution of the Poincare Conjecture. Find specific links  that have the 4x5 chessboard complex as their complement.

title: Approximation ratio for k-outerplanar graphs

title: Are there an infinite number of lucky primes?
description: Conjecture If every second positive integer except 2 is remaining, then every third remaining integer except 3, then every fourth remaining integer etc. , an infinite number of the remaining integers are prime.

title: Something like Picard for 1-forms

title: The robustness of the tensor product
description: Problem Given two codes , their Tensor Product is the code that consists of the matrices whose rows are codewords of and whose columns are codewords of . The product is said to be robust if whenever a matrix is far from , the rows (columns) of are far from ( , respectively). The problem is to give a characterization of the pairs whose tensor product is robust.

description: Conjecture Given any complex numbers which are linearly independent over the rational numbers , then the extension field has transcendence degree of at least over .

title: What is the homotopy type of the group of diffeomorphisms of the 4-sphere?
description: Problem has the homotopy-type of a product space where is the group of diffeomorphisms of the 4-ball which restrict to the identity on the boundary.  Determine some (any?) homotopy or homology groups of .

title: Which compact boundaryless 3-manifolds embed smoothly in the 4-sphere?
description: Problem Determine a computable set of invariants that allow one to determine, given a compact boundaryless 3-manifold, whether or not it embeds smoothly in the 4-sphere.  This should include a constructive procedure to find an embedding if the manifold is embeddable.

title: Realisation problem for the space of knots in the 3-sphere
description: Problem Given a link in , let the symmetry group of be denoted ie: isotopy classes of diffeomorphisms of which preserve , where the isotopies are also required to preserve . Now let be a hyperbolic link. Assume has the further `Brunnian' property that there exists a component of such that is the unlink.  Let be the subgroup of consisting of diffeomorphisms of which preserve together with its orientation, and which preserve the orientation of . There is a representation given by restricting the diffeomorphism to the .  It's known that is always a cyclic group.  And is a signed symmetric group -- the wreath product of a symmetric group with . Problem: What representations can be obtained?

title: Slice-ribbon problem
description: Conjecture Given a knot in which is slice, is it a ribbon knot?

title: Smooth 4-dimensional Schoenflies problem
description: Problem Let be a -dimensional smooth submanifold of , diffeomorphic to .  By the Jordan-Brouwer separation theorem, separates into the union of two compact connected -manifolds which share as a common boundary.  The Schoenflies problem asks, are these -manifolds diffeomorphic to ? ie: is unknotted?

title: Distribution and upper bound of mimic numbers
description: Problem Let the notation denote '' divides ''. The mimic function in number theory is defined as follows [1]. Definition For any positive integer divisible by , the mimic function is given by, By using this definition of mimic function, the mimic number of any non-prime integer is defined as follows [1]. Definition The number is defined to be the mimic number of any positive integer , with respect to , for the minimum value of which . Given these two definitions and a positive integer , find the distribution of mimic numbers of those numbers divisible by . Again, find whether there is an upper bound of mimic numbers for a set of numbers divisible by any fixed positive integer .

title: Refuting random 3SAT-instances on $O(n)$ clauses (weak form)
description: Conjecture For every rational and every rational , there is no polynomial-time algorithm for the following problem. Given is a 3SAT (3CNF) formula on variables, for some , and clauses drawn uniformly at random from the set of formulas on variables. Return with probability at least 0.5 (over the instances) that is typical without returning typical for any instance with at least simultaneously satisfiable clauses.

title: Total Colouring Conjecture
description: Conjecture A total coloring of a graph is an assignment of colors to the vertices and the edges of such that every pair of adjacent vertices, every pair of adjacent edges and every vertex and incident edge pair, receive different colors. The total chromatic number of a graph  equals the minimum number of colors needed in a total coloring of . It is an old conjecture of Behzad that for every graph , the total chromatic number equals the maximum degree of a vertex in , plus one or two. In other words,

description: Conjecture Let be the disjoint union of the graphs and and let be a surface.  Is it true that every optimal drawing of on has the property that and are disjoint?

title: Matchings extend to Hamiltonian cycles in hypercubes
description: Question Does every matching of hypercube extend to a Hamiltonian cycle ?

title: Linear Hypergraphs with Dimension 3
authors: de Fraysseix, Ossona de Mendez, Rosenstiehl
description: Conjecture Any linear hypergraph with incidence poset of dimension at most 3 is the intersection hypergraph of a family of triangles and segments in the plane.

title: Reed's omega, delta, and chi conjecture
description: Conjecture for every graph .

title: Pebbling a cartesian product
description: Conjecture .

title: Rendezvous on a line
description: Problem Two players start at a distance of 2 on an (undirected) line (so, neither player knows the direction of the other) and both move at a maximum speed of 1.  What is the infimum expected meeting time (first time when the players occupy the same point) which can be achieved assuming the two players must adopt the same strategy?

title: Linial-Berge path partition duality
description: Conjecture The minimum -norm of a path partition on a directed graph is no more than the maximal size of an induced -colorable subgraph.

title: What is the smallest number of disjoint spanning trees made a graph Hamiltonian

title: Coloring and immersion
description: Conjecture For every positive integer , every (loopless) graph with immerses .

title: Rainbow AP(4) in an almost equinumerous coloring
description: Problem Do 4-colorings of , for a large prime, always contain a rainbow if each of the color classes is of size of either or ?

title: The intersection of two perfect matchings
description: Conjecture Every bridgeless cubic graph has two perfect matchings , so that does not contain an odd edge-cut.

title: Counterexamples to the Baillie-PSW primality test
description: Problem  (1) Find a counterexample to Baillie-PSW primality test or prove that there is no one.

title: A sextic counterexample to Euler's sum of powers conjecture
description: Problem Find six positive integers such that or prove that such integers do not exist.

title: Geodesic cycles and Tutte's Theorem
description: Problem If is a -connected finite graph, is there an assignment of lengths to the edges of , such that every -geodesic cycle is peripheral ?
kwds: cycle space, geodesic cycles, peripheral cycles

title: Oriented chromatic number of planar graphs
description: Problem What is the maximal possible oriented chromatic number of an oriented planar graph?
kwds: oriented coloring, oriented graph, planar graph

title: Covering systems with big moduli
description: Problem Does for every integer exist a covering system with all moduli distinct and at least equal to~ ?

title: Odd incongruent covering systems
description: Conjecture There is no covering system whose moduli are odd, distinct, and greater than 1.

title: Hamiltonian cycles in powers of infinite graphs
description: Conjecture \item If is a countable connected graph then its third power is hamiltonian. \item If is a 2-connected countable graph then its square is hamiltonian.

title: Hamiltonian cycles in line graphs of infinite graphs
description: Conjecture \item If is a 4-edge-connected locally finite graph, then its line graph is hamiltonian. \item If the line graph of a locally finite graph is 4-connected, then is hamiltonian.

title: Hamiltonian cycles in line graphs
description: Conjecture Every 4-connected line graph is hamiltonian .

title: Infinite uniquely hamiltonian graphs
description: Problem Are there any uniquely hamiltonian locally finite 1-ended graphs which are regular of degree ?

title: Linear-size circuits for stable $0,1 < 2$ sorting?
description: Problem Can -size circuits compute the function on defined inductively by  , and ?

title: Unconditional derandomization of Arthur-Merlin games
description: Problem Prove unconditionally that .

title: Subset-sums equality (pigeonhole version)
description: Problem Let be natural numbers with .  It follows from the pigeon-hole principle that there exist distinct subsets with .  Is it possible to find such a pair in polynomial time?

title: Weak pentagon problem
description: Conjecture If is a cubic graph not containing a triangle, then it is possible to color the edges of by five colors, so that  the complement of every color class is a bipartite graph.
kwds: Clebsch graph, cut-continuous mapping, edge-coloring, homomorphism, pentagon

title: Lonely runner conjecture
description: Conjecture Suppose runners having distinct constant speeds start at a common point and run laps on a circular track with circumference 1. Then for any given runner, there is a time at which that runner is distance at least (along the track) away from every other runner.

title: Mapping planar graphs to odd cycles
description: Conjecture Every planar graph of girth has a homomorphism to .

title: 5-local-tensions
description: Conjecture There exists a fixed constant (probably suffices) so that every embedded (loopless) graph with edge-width has a 5-local-tension.

title: Concavity of van der Waerden numbers
description: Conjecture For all and with , .

title: Circular coloring triangle-free subcubic planar graphs
description: Problem Does every triangle-free planar graph of maximum degree three have circular chromatic number at most ?
kwds: circular coloring, planar graph, triangle free

title: List colorings of edge-critical graphs
description: Conjecture Suppose that is a -edge-critical graph. Suppose that for each edge of , there is a list of colors.  Then is -edge-colorable unless all lists are equal to each other.

title: Aharoni-Berger conjecture
description: Conjecture If are matroids on and for every partition of , then there exists with which is independent in every .

title: The large sets conjecture
description: Conjecture If is 2-large, then is large.

title: Ramsey properties of Cayley graphs
description: Conjecture There exists a fixed constant so that every abelian group has a subset with so that the Cayley graph has no clique or independent set of size .

title: The Erdos-Turan conjecture on additive bases
description: Conjecture If is an additive basis, then is unbounded.

title: Rota's unimodal conjecture
description: Conjecture is unimodal.

title: A conjecture on iterated circumcentres
description: Conjecture Let be a sequence of points in with the property that for every , the points are distinct, lie on a unique sphere, and further, is the center of this sphere.  If this sequence is periodic, must its period be ?

title: Unions of triangle free graphs
description: Problem Does there exist a graph with no subgraph isomorphic to which cannot be expressed as a union of triangle free graphs?
kwds: forbidden subgraph, infinite graph, triangle free

title: The Two Color Conjecture
description: Conjecture If is an orientation of a simple planar graph, then there is a partition of into so that the graph induced by is acyclic for .

title: Half-integral flow polynomial values
description: Conjecture for every 2-edge-connected graph .

title: Gao's theorem for nonabelian groups
description: Conjecture for every finite group .

title: Universal point sets for planar graphs
description: Question Does there exist an -universal set of size ?
kwds: geometric graph, planar graph, universal set

title: Antichains in the cycle continuous order
description: Problem Does there exist an infinite set of graphs so that there is no cycle continuous mapping between and whenever ?

title: Fat 4-polytopes
description: Question Does there exist a fixed constant so that every convex 4-polytope has fatness at most ?

description: Conjecture

title: Woodall's Conjecture
description: Conjecture If is a directed graph with smallest directed cut of size , then has disjoint dijoins.

title: Pentagon problem
description: Question Let be a 3-regular graph that contains no cycle of length shorter than . Is it true that for large enough~ there is a homomorphism ?

title: Ryser's conjecture
description: Conjecture Let be an - uniform -partite hypergraph.  If is the maximum number of pairwise disjoint edges in , and is the size of the smallest set of vertices which meets every edge, then .

title: The Erdös-Hajnal Conjecture
description: Conjecture For every fixed graph , there exists a constant , so that every graph without an induced subgraph isomorphic to contains either a clique or an independent set of size .

title: Hamiltonian paths and cycles in vertex transitive graphs
description: Problem Does every connected vertex-transitive graph have a Hamiltonian path ?

title: 57-regular Moore graph?
description: Question Does there exist a 57- regular graph with diameter 2 and girth 5?

title: Few subsequence sums in $Z_n$ x $Z_n$
description: Conjecture For every , the sequence in consisting of copes of and copies of has the fewest number of distinct subsequence sums over all zero-free sequences from of length .

title: Olson's Conjecture
description: Conjecture If is a sequence of elements from a multiplicative group of order , then there exist so that .

title: Jorgensen's Conjecture
description: Conjecture Every 6- connected graph without a minor is apex (planar plus one vertex).

title: Highly connected graphs with no $K_n$ minor
description: Problem Is it true for all , that every sufficiently large - connected graph without a minor has a set of vertices whose deletion results in a planar graph ?

title: The Alon-Tarsi basis conjecture
description: Conjecture If are invertible matrices with entries in for a prime , then there is a submatrix of so that is an AT-base.

title: The permanent conjecture
description: Conjecture If is an invertible matrix, then there is an submatrix of so that is nonzero.

title: The additive basis conjecture
description: Conjecture For every prime , there is a constant (possibly ) so that the union (as multisets) of any bases of the vector space contains an additive basis.

title: A nowhere-zero point in a linear mapping
description: Conjecture If is a finite field with at least 4 elements and is an invertible matrix with entries in , then there are column vectors which have no coordinates equal to zero such that .

title: Partitioning edge-connectivity
description: Question Let be an - edge-connected graph. Does there exist a partition of so that is -edge-connected and is -edge-connected?

title: Acyclic edge-colouring
description: Conjecture Every simple graph with maximum degree has a proper - edge-colouring so that every cycle contains edges of at least three distinct colours.

title: Packing T-joins
description: Conjecture There exists a fixed constant (probably suffices) so that every graft with minimum -cut size at least contains a -join packing of size at least .

title: Decomposing eulerian graphs
description: Conjecture If is a 6- edge-connected Eulerian graph and is a 2-transition system for , then has a compaible decomposition.

title: Faithful cycle covers
description: Conjecture If is a graph, is admissable, and is even for every , then has a faithful cover.

title: (m,n)-cycle covers
description: Conjecture Every bridgeless graph has a (5,2)-cycle-cover.

title: The circular embedding conjecture
description: Conjecture Every 2- connected graph may be embedded in a surface so that the boundary of each face is a cycle.

title: Unit vector flows
description: Conjecture For every graph without a bridge , there is a flow .

title: A homomorphism problem for flows
description: Conjecture Let be abelian groups and let and satisfy and .  If there is a homomorphism from to , then every graph with a B-flow has a B'-flow.

title: The three 4-flows conjecture
description: Conjecture For every graph with no bridge , there exist three disjoint sets with so that has a nowhere-zero 4-flow for .

title: Bouchet's 6-flow conjecture
description: Conjecture Every bidirected graph with a nowhere-zero -flow for some , has a nowhere-zero -flow.

title: Jaeger's modular orientation conjecture
description: Conjecture Every - edge-connected graph can be oriented so that (mod ) for every vertex .

title: 5-flow conjecture
description: Conjecture Every bridgeless graph has a nowhere-zero 5-flow.
